REPORT AND RECOMMENDATiON OF THE PRESIDENT
TO THE BOARD OF DiRECTORS ON A PROPOSED LOAN TO MALAYSIA FOR
THE THIRD PENANG PORT EXPANSION PROJECT
1. 1 submit to the Board of Directors, for their consideration
and decision, the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan from the ordinary capital resources of the Bank in an amount in
various currencies equivalent to US$45.8 million to the Penang Port
Commission (PPC) for the Third Penang Port Expansion Project. The
proposed loan will have a term of 20 years, including a grace period
of 4 years, with interest of 10.25 per cent per annum. The loan will
be guaranteed by Malaysia.
2. in 1977, the Bank financed under the Second Penang Port
Expansion Project 1/ the provision of consultant services to prepare a
feasibility study for the third phase of port development. The study
was completed by the consultants 2/ in October 1981. Subsequent to a
Bank's Fact-Finding Mission in August 1982, an Appraisal Mission
visited Malaysia from 27 June to 8 July 1983, and firmed up the scope
and the implementation arrangements for the Project in consultation
with the relevant authorities of the Government, PPC and other
agencies concerned. Further processing of the proposed Bank loan was,
however, withheld due to the Government investment priority review
undertaken during the second half of 1983 and the Mid-Term Review of
the Fourth Malaysia Plan approved in early 1984. In view of the
recognized urgency of expanded port facilities at Penang, the
Government suggested, in early June 1984, the Bank consider the
proposed loan being made to PPC with the Government guarantee. A Bank
Follow-Up Mission visited Penang and Kuala Lumpur, from 18 to 22 June
1984, to review the Project cost estimates, the PPC's financial
position and the financing plan for the Project. Formal loan
negotiations for the proposed loan with authorized representatives of
PPC (the Borrower) and Malaysia (the Guarantor) were held In Manila
from 23 to 25 July 1984. If approved, the proposed loan will be the
Bank's fifty-second loan to Malaysia and the seventh for the port
subsector.
I. THE ECONOMY
3. An Economic Memorandum on Malaysia (Report No. MAL:Ec-6s-2)
was circulated to the Board in December 1980. Economic developments
since then are highlighted in the following paragraphs. Basic Data
for Malaysia are presented in Appendix 1.
1/ Loan No. 296-MAL, US$10.00 million, approved on 29 March 1977.
(Doc. No. R23-77, 8 March 1977).
2/ E. G. Frankel, Inc. (USA), in association with Sepakat Setia
Perunding Sdn. Bhd. (Malaysia).

2
A. Recent Economic Developments
1. Introduction
4. During the 1970s real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) expanded
by 7.8 per cent per annum supported by high rates of growth in
domestic savings and investment and accompanied by a high degree of
domestic price stability. This commendable growth performance was
attributable to several factors including the country's rich natural
resources, the Government's well-conceived growth strategy and prudent
financial management, social and political stability, and a generally
favorable external environment. The population was estimated at 14.7
million in 1983, and the per capita Gross National Product (GNP) of
Malaysia stood at $1,840 1/ in 1982. During the decade, remarkable
progress was also made on the socio-economic front. The Government
formulated a long-term New Economic Policy (NEP) in 1971, which called
for the eradication of poverty and reduction of ethnic imbalances in
the distribution of income, employment and asset ownership. The 1970s
witnessed substantial headway towards the attainment of the NEP
objectives. The growth of employment at 4.1 per cent per annum was
faster than that of the labor force, which increased at the rate of
3.9 per cent per annum during the 1970s. In particular, employment in
manufacturing grew at an average annual rate of 8.5 per cent and
constituted 15.6 per cent of total employment in 1980 as against 9.0
per cent in 1970. The overall incidence of poverty 2/ in Peninsular
Malaysia was reduced from 49 per cent in 1970 to 29 per cent in 1980,
but increased slightly to 30.3 per cent in 1983.
5. In contrast to the impressive performance in the 1970s, the
pace of the Malaysian economy slowed down in the 1980s. The slower
rate of growth was associated with a deterioration in the financial
resource position and rapidly enlarging fiscal deficits.
2. Overall Growth Performance
6. The growth rate of real GDP declined to 7.1 per cent in 1981
and further to 5.6 per cent in 1982. In 1983 the growth rate improved
slightly but remained relatively low at 5.8 per cent. The slowdown in
overall economic growth during 1981-1983 was primarily due to a marked
decline in the growth of aggregate demand. The decline was associated
if World Bank estimate using 1980-1982 as base period.
2/ Proportion of persons with incomes below the poverty line in the
total population. The poverty line W98 drawn by the Government at
M$290 per household per month or M$55 per person per month for
1980. Subsequently the Mid-Term Review of the Fourth Malaysia
Plan (March, 1984) indicates that the poverty line has been
adjusted annually by taking into account changes in the Consumer
Price Indices, but does not give an absolute poverty line income
figure for 1983.

3
with contractionary monetary policy, a sharp reduction in the rate of
Government expenditure initiated in mid-1982 and adverse external
developments resulting from world recession. A steep decline in
external demand and in export prices for nearly all major exports
of Malaysia resulted in a deceleration in the annual rate of growth of
real exports and non-factor services from 9.3 per cent during
1976-1980 to about 6 per cent during 1981-1982. However, estimates
for 1983 indicate an upturn to 13 per cent as some revival of external
demand was registered. On the domestic front, a decline in the growth
of disposable income resulted in annual growth of 4.5 per cent in real
private consumption during 1982-1983. The slowdown in consumer demand
coupled with an uncertain business outlook resulted in a considerable
deceleration of the growth of real private investment to an annual
rate of 5.8 per cent during 1982-1983 as against 17 per cent during
1980-1981. The public sector, which was the major source of growth in
demand during 1980-1981 also contributed to the weakening of domestic
demand in the period 1982-1983. During 1980-1981 and the first half
of 1982, the Government's fiscal operations were expansionary with a
view to counteracting the impact of recession. In mid-1982, however,
the Government began to cut its expenditure. Accordingly, the growth
of real public expenditure has decelerated since 1982 and has
increased by only 7.5 per cent per annum during 1982-1983 compared
with 21.5 per cent per annum during 1980-1981. In particular, real
public investment fell by 11 per cent in 1983.
7. Sectorally, growth performance in most sectors improved in
1983 with the exception of agriculture. Estimated real value-added in
the agriculture sector increased by only 0.5 per cent as against 7.4
per cent in 1982, largely because of a fall in palm oil output. The
estimated growth in the construction sector accelerated to 15.0 per
cent from 9.5 per cent in 1982. In 1983 estimated value-added in the
manufacturing sector showed a rate of increase of 6.0 per cent from
3.8 per cent in 1982 and in the services sector rose marginally to 7.0
per cent. Estimated growth of the mining sector also accelerated
sharply in 1983 to 16.2 per cent from 2.8 per cent in 1982 as crude
petroleum production further increased and liquefied natural gas came
on stream. Tin production, however, showed a continued fall in 1983.
3. Fiscal Operations
8. The counter-cyclical thrust of fiscal operations resulted in
a rapid expansion of total expenditure of the Federal Government from
40.4 per cent of GDP in 1980 to 47 per cent in 1981. Government
revenues also increased but at a slower rate mainly because of a fall
in receipts from non-petroleum export taxes. Consequently, the
overall fiscal deficit increased from an annual average level of 8 per
cent of GDP to 13.6 per cent of GOP in 1980 and further to 16.0 per
cent in 1981 and 19.5 per cent in 1982. The prolonged world recession
resulted in a reduced rate of growth in tax revenues leading the
Government in mid-1982 to initiate expenditure curtailment. in 1982
the nominal total Government expenditure, declined by 2.0 per cent
compared with an annual average increase of 37 per cent during
1980-1981.

4
The principal focus of the 1983 and 1984 budgets has been
the continued deceleration of the rate o. increase in total Government
expenditure. The persisting uncertainty in respect of the country's
financial resource prospects led the Government to undertake a review
in 1983 of the overall public investment program. Development
expenditure was cut by an estimated 8 per cent in 1983 and the 1984
budget provides for further cuts of 23 per cent. Local expenditure on
several of the on-going projects (including those financed by external
agencies) have been curtailed since mid-1983. In addition, to
accelerate domestic resource mobilization, the 1983 and 1984 budgets
contained a number of tax-enhancing measures such as doubling of
sales tax on most non-essential products and increasing import duties
on a wide range of goods. In addition, the 1984 budget provided for
tax exemption of interest earned by individuals on Government
securities to widen the investment base of these securities. Despite
these measures and severe restraints on expenditure, the fiscal
deficit was estimated at the relatively high level of 14.5 per cent of
GDP in 1983 and is forecast at 10 per cent of GDP in 1984.
10. Prior to these adjustments, the Government increased the
level of its borrowing rapidly to finance the fiscal deficits. In the
past, the Government financed fiscal deficits mainly through domestic
sources such as the Employees' Provident Fund. From 1981 however the
Government increasingly resorted to external borrowings to meet its
deficit. External borrowings reached an estimated M$5.2 billion in
l83 compared with an annual average of M$0.5 billion during
1976-1980. From an average of 20 per cent of total Government
borrowing in 1976-1980, external borrowing rose to an average of 47
per cent in 1981-1983. Commercial loans have been the principal
component of the growth in external borrowing and constituted 88 per
cent of such borrowing in 1981-1983.
4. Money and Prices
11. in 1981-1983 monetary and credit operations were less
expansionary than in the previous years mainly due to a slow growth in
demand for bank credits from the private sector and a decline in net
foreign assets reflecting the weakening of the balance-of-payments
position. The rate of monetary expansion decelerated from an annual
average of 18 per cent during 1976-1980 to about 9 per cent during
198 1-1983.
12. Following a long period of price stability, the economy
experienced inflationary pressure in 1981. The annual rate of
domestic inflation as measured by the consumer price index rose from
an average of 4.5 per cent during 1976-1980 to 9.7 per cent in 1981.
The main contributing factors to the acceleration of inflation were
sharp increases in import prices and sustained growth in domestic
demand associated with increased rate of investment and rapid

5
expansion of liquidity in the preceding years. The inflation rate,
however, decelerated to 5.8 per cent in 1982 and further to 4.0 per
cent in 1983. This favorable trend was partly due to the decline in
the rate of monetary expansion and partly due to a slowdown in the
rate of growth of import prices, Itself attributable to some extent to
a minor appreciation of the rInggit against most trading currencies
other than the U.S. dollar.
5. Balance of Payments
13. Malaysia's balance of payments, which had remained favorable
for over a decade till 1980, deteriorated rapidly in 1981 and 1982.
Total commodity export earnings declined by about 3.5 per cent per
annum during 1981-1982 in contrast to a 25 per cent annual increase
during 1976-1980. Import payments, however, increased by 9.1 per cent
per annum during 1981-1982 mainly because of an increase In import
prices. Consequently, the merchandise trade balance showed a deficit
in 1981 for the first time In more than two decades. The deficit
reached US$0.7 billion in 1982. The deterioration In the trade
account resulted in the current account deficit widening to US$2.3
billion in 1981 and further to US$3.4 billion in 1982 (12.4 per cent
of GDP). The current account deficits were met by capital Inflows
which Increased from US$1.4 billion in 1980 to US$3.7 billion in 1982.
After taking Into account net errors and omissions, the overall
balance of payments registered a deficit of US$0.5 billion in 1981 and
US$0.3 billion in 1982.
14. In 1983 Malaysia's balance-of-payments situation showed
improvement. The merchandise trade balance moved Into surplus as a
result of a sharp upturn in the growth of exports following favorable
trends in external price and volume for most commodities and a
deceleration in the rate of growth of Imports. The current account
deficit declined to US$2.8 billion (10 per cent of GDP) and
preliminary estimates indicate a small overall balance-of-payments
deficit in 1983. At the end of 1983 the country's international
reserves stood at US$3.9 billion. Despite strong Improvement expected
in the merchandise trade balance, a deficit on the current account of
about Us$2.0 billion is expected in 1984 as continued widening of the
deficit in the flow of investment income Is forecast.
6. External Borrowing and Debts
15. Prior to 1981 Malaysia's external borrowings remained
modest. Since 1981, however, external borrowings, notably borrowings
from the International capital market, Increased markedly reflecting
the country's need to finance a widening resource gap. in 1981
Malaysia secured project loans totalling US$0.34 billion from
multilateral financial institutions, including the Bank, and various
bilateral sources. In addition, Malaysia also raised market loans
totalling US$1.2 billion. In 1982 the country's project loans from
bilateral and multilateral sources amounted to US$0.3 billion and its

borrowings from the international capital market totalled US$1.8
billion. At the end of 1982 (the latest year for which data are
available), total external public debt outstanding (disbursed only
amounted to US$7.7 billion. Of the disbursed debt of the Federal
Government in 1982, 72 per cent was market loans, 15 per cent from
multilateral agencies and 13 per cent from bilateral sources. The
country borrowed about US$2.2 billion in 1983.
16. Total debt-service payments (external and domestic), which
rose sharply during 1982-1983, have been forecast to be 25 per cent of
Government operating expenditure in 1984. Although the external
debt-service ratio was estimated at only 6.0 per cent in 1983 -- up
from 2.5 per cent in 1980 -- the ratio is expected to move to 8 to 10
per cent in 1984 and 1985 as a result of the large-scale commercial
credits contracted in recent years. The Government has expressed
concern at the prospective bunching of external debt repayments in the
latter half of the 1980g.
7. Development Strategy and Prospect
17. Malaysia's long-term development strategy and objectives are
set forth in the NEP and in the Outline Perspective Plan (0PP)
covering the period 1971-1990. The main objective proclaimed in the
NEP is consolidation of national unity. Towards this goal, the NEP
seeks: (i) to eradicate poverty; and (ii) to reduce imbalance among
the ethnic groups in terms of income, employment and ownership of
assets. These objectives are sought to be achieved through rapid
economic expansion with price stability. The Fourth Malaysia Plan
(1981-1985), which represents the third five-year plan formulated
within the NEP and OPP framework, was launched in March 1981. The
Fourth Plan targets for 1981-]985 include annual expansion of real CDP
by 7.6 per cent, real gross domestic investment by 5.6 per cent and
employment by 3.2 per cent. Malaysia's development plans do not
explicitly indicate an order of sectoral development priorities. In
terms of relative magnitudes of public investment allocations, the
implicit order of priority in the Fourth Plan is agricultural and
rural development, accounting for 19.5 per cent of the total original
development budget allocations, followed by transport and
communications (13.2 per cent), commerce and industry (12.7 per cent),
housing, health, sanitation and community development and services
(7.6 per cent), energy and public utilities (7.5 per cent) and
education (7.0 per cent). The remaining planned expenditure is mainly
for non-economic sectors such as security and administration. !/
18. The prospects of a relatively high rate of economic growth
appear less favorable in the medium term. While Malaysia's natural
resources endowment and its past economic performance augur well for

7
the country's economic progress in the longer term, the economy has
been experiencing a slowdown in overall growth in the shorter term
mainly because of the slow world economic recovery and substantial
cuts in public investment. The official forecast of economic growth
for 1984 is 6.7 per cent, still below the target set for the Fourth
Malaysia Plan.
19. The Mid-Term Review of the Fourth Malaysia Plan was
presented in March 1984. The Review highlighted the less favorable
economic climate and performance, 1981 to 1983, than anticipated under
the Fourth Malaysia Plan. The annual expansion of real CDP and of
employment over the Plan period has been revised downward to 6.4 per
cent and 3.0 per cent, respectively. An unemployment rate of 6.2 per
cent in 1985 has been forecast in the Review as compared with a
forecast of 4.9 per cent in that year under the Fourth Malaysia Plan.
Notwithstanding good progress made in the past, the problems of
poverty and imbalance in income distribution continue to persist in
Malaysia. The incidence of poverty is still high (30 per cent in 1983
in Peninsular Malaysia); the poor are mainly in the rural areas (86
per cent in 1983) where the majority of Bumiputras !/ reside. An
overall incidence of poverty of 24 per cent in 1985 in Peninsular
Malaysia Is forecast in the Review. Total public development
expenditure has been revised to M$59.7 billion in the Review from
M$42.8 billion under the original Fourth Malaysia Plan with
expenditure in the years 1981 to 1983 estimated at M$40.4 billion.
Revised sectoral. allocations in the Review for the Plan period have
been made as follows: agricultural and rural development (13.4 per
cent), transport and communications (16.3 per cent), commerce and
industry (11.8 per cent), housing, health, sanitation and community
development and services (10.9 per cent), energy and public  utilities
(8.0 per cent) and education (7.7 per cent).
20. The Fourth Plan aims at moving toward the eradication of
poverty and restructuring of the economy through rapid growth of
non-agricultural sectors, in particular manufacturing. However,
achievement of rapid industrialization simultaneously with other NEP
objectives would call for broadening and diversification of industrial
activities based on improved skills and technology. This will require
increasing investments which, In turn, would call for favorable
policies and an investment climate -- domestic and external --
conducive to private investment as well as availability of Indigenous
human resources. While the first requirement calls for early
formulation of an integrated national industrial policy, the latter
underlines the need for the preparation and implementation of
appropriate manpower programs. These objectives have been given
renewed and strengthened emphasis within the Mid-Term Review.
1/ Literally means "sons of the soil" and refers to Malays and other
indigenous people.

8
21. The emphasis on rapid industrial growth does not minimize
the importance of agriculture in the economy and its role in the
achievement of the NEP objectives. However, the agriculture sector  Ic
experiencing difficulties resulting from the changing demographic
situation wherein there is a movement of the young and educated away
from the rural sector, coinciding with absolute labor shortages. The
Government has recognized that unless sustained efforts are made to
solve the problems facing agriculture, the NEP objectives may not be
full.y achieved. Accordingly, it announced in January 1984 a National
Agricultural Policy focused upon action to redress deterioration of
the agricultural resource base of the economy, and promoting increased
sector productivity and enhanced farm incomes. These objectives have
been incorporated within the Mid-Term Review.
22. While the Fourth Plan places increased emphasis on the role
of the private sector, public investment is expected to continue to
play an important role in the development of physical and social
infrastructure as well as in the implementation of programs aimed at
reducing poverty. The Mid-Term Review has, however, emphasized the
need to privatize selected Government services and interests to
accelerate the pace of restructuring and to accommodate a more
restrictive public investment climate. Nevertheless, the public
sector will be constrained by its limited capacity to formulate and
implement investment programs and projects. Continued assistance to
Malaysia from multilateral financial institutions would be required as
such assistance would strengthen the public sector's implementation
capacity, besides helping the country to overcome its increasing
resource constraint.
B. The Port Sector
23. The provision of an efficient and balanced transport system
is an integral part of the Malaysia's development process. During the
past decade, the expansion and modernization of port facilities has
made a significant contribution towards greater inter and
intra regional movement. During the Fourth Plan period (1981-1985),
various modes of transport and related infrastructure are planned to
be further expanded and improved to accelerate the soclo-economic
development of the country. In this context, ports will be developed
to enable them to cope with growing traffic and other related maritime
activities.
24. The Economic Planning Unit (EPU) of the Prime Minister's
Department through its Transport Section is responsible for the
formulation of macro-economic plans and for the overall sectoral
planning of the transport sector in collaboration with the ministries
and departments concerned. The Ministry of Transport is responsible
for the formulation, evaluation and implementation of transport
policies, and for development programs and projects.

9
25. in 1982, a total of 17.4 million tons of cargo was handled
by the Peninsular Malayia ports in comparison with 7.9 million tons
In 1970, representing an average annual increase in port traffic of
6.8 per cent during the period; this growth rate is expected by the
Government to increase further, at an average annual rate of 9.5 per
cent or to 25.5 million tons by 1985. The port system of Peninsular
Malaysia has been dominated by two international deepwater ports viz.,
the ports of Kelang and Penang. lii 1982, about 82 per cent of the
total volume of the international trade of the Peninsular was handled
through these two ports, with the balance handled mainly through
Johore Port. While the share of total traffic of Penang Port has
increased from 35 per cent in 1976 to about 39 per cent in 1982, that
of Port Kelang declined from about 60 per cent to 43 per cent during
the same period. During the period 1970-1980, Port Kelang's annual
cargo handling capacity was expanded from about 4.4 million tons in
1970 to 8.0 million tons in 1980. By the end of FMP 1985 the capacity
of Port Kelang, Including the expansion program for Pulau Lumut, is
expected to be increased to about 14 million tons. The cargo handling
capacity of Penang Port was increased from some 2.0 million tons in
1970 to 5.5 million tons by 1981. Under FMP, the capacity is planned
to be Increased to about 9.0 million tons with the implementation of
the proposed North Butterworth container terminal project and the
construction of an additional berth for the existing bulk cargo
terminal. The expansion program for Johore Port, which aims to
increase its capacity from 3.5 million tons in 1980 to about 7.5
million tons by 1985, includes the construction of an additional
multi-purpose berth, two berths for dry bulk cargo and a dangerous
cargo jetty. Kuantan Port, located on the east coast of Peninsular
Malaysia, has been developed with Bank assistance. 1/ There are two
smaller ports, at Kemasin and Kemaman, on the east coast of Peninsular
Malaysia.
26. The total capacity planned to be developed for the entire
Peninsular Malaysia ports system during the FM? period (1981-1985) is
about 30 million tons, which will be barely adequate for the period up
to 1990, assuming same growth In traffic as observed during the 1970s.
27. The Bank has so far provided two loans for the development
of the Port of Penang -- the Penang Port Expansion Project (Loan No.
184-MAL, approved in April 1984) and the Second Penang Port Expansion
(Loan No. 296-MAL, approved in March 1977). The first project
provided for the construction of a general cargo wharf, a transmit
shed at the Butterworth Wharves (Berth No. 6), and a bulk cargo
terminal at Prai. The second project involved the conversion of Berth
No. 6 to a container cum roll on-roll off berth and the construction
of a vegetable oil berth. It also provided for consultant services to

prepare a feasibility study for the Phase 111 development of the port
and a tariff study. A Project Completion Mission in February 1981 1/
and a Post Evaluation Mission in March 1983 2/ have both concluded

II. BANK OPERATiONS iN MALAYSIA
A. Past Operations
29. Bank operations in Malaysia started in 1968. By 31 July 1984
the Bank had approved 51 loans totalling US$885.128 million for 50
projects. Of these loans, 50, amounting to US$881.828 million, were
from its ordinary capital resources, and one loan, of US$3.3 million,
was from Special Funds resources. In addition, technical assistance
amounting to US$3.292 million was provided for 18 projects, of which
six have resulted in Bank loans amounting to US$145.3 million.
Co-financing in an amount of US$279.61 million with bilateral,
multilateral and commercial sources has so far been arranged for seven
projects.
30. Bank lending to Malaysia has expanded from an average level
of about $50 million annually in the mid-1970s to $92.58 million in
1982. Lending in 1983 declined to $82.51 million, however, due to a
Government review of investment priorities and external borrowings
undertaken during that year. The sectoral distribution of cumulative
Bank lending to Malaysia is shown below.

on lending for physical infrastructure projects located in the

the Bank's developmental role in Malaysia would be further enhanced by

designed to eradicate poverty. A gradual shift in the Bank's

assistance activities in Malaysia, followed by energy (US$798,000;
2.24 per cent), urban development (US$550,000; 16.71 per cent), water

(Us$292,000; 8.87 per cent).
33. Of the 50 projects assisted by the Bank loans, 29 have been
completed and the loans closed. The Bank has so far approved one
supplementary loan for a road project. Cost overruns in some other
projects have been borne by the Government. Disbursement as of 31
May 1984 amounted to US$441.624 million, or about 55.81 per cent of
the total available for withdrawal. The Bank generally has not
encountered problems in Malaysia regarding adherence to loan
covenants, and progress in implementation of the majority of
Bank-financed projects in Malaysia has been satisfactory. However, in
the cases of a few projects there have been delays in project start-up
and completion because of initial delays in procurement of equipment,
recruitment of consultants, and prequalification of contractors. The
reasons for the delays in these cases have been discussed with the

F. Operational Strategy
34. Within the framework of Malaysia's development priorities,
the lending program is guided by the Bank's strategic approach to
country programming. This approach is necessarily long-term and
evolutionary in nature and the Bank's lending portfolio in the coming
years will increasingly reflect three strategic objectives: support
for structural change, efficient resource use, and institutional
development. In this context two areas which are of prime importance
are poverty eradication and energy development.

13
5. Despite high per-capita income, widespread poverty and
social imbalance are prevalent in 11alaysia and countering this
situation is the main thrust of the development programs of the
Government; the Bank's operational strategy supports this development
thrust. The Bank has adopted a multipronged approach to meet this
challenge, through assistance to the agriculture sector (where the
incidence of poverty is as high as 42 per Cent), manpower development,
and the provision of social intrastructure facilities. In the
agriculture sector the National Agricultural Policy aims at improving
the contribution of the sector to the national economy through
qualitative and quantitative change In farm productivity and income
pattern of farm holders through emphasizing activities with greater
returns to labor, selective cropping patterns, tood crop development
and land utilization measures. Special attention will be paid to the
development of sector institutions. Bank lending over the next few
years will broadly support this thrust, and the sector will continue
to remain in sharp focus in the Bank's strategy. Manpower development
programs will play a supplemental role in poverty alleviation by
facilitating increased absorption of skilled labor in non-agricultural
activities through rehabilitation and expansion ot technical and
vocational educational institutions. The Bank's assistance to the
social infrastructure subsector will aim at providing basic needs of
the poor through projects for urban and rural development, rural
water supply and health facilities.
36. The energy sector is another focus ot the Bank's strategy.
Exploitation of the country's considerable natural gas reserves tor
domestic consumption and tor export, the development of hydroelectric
power, and a broader diversification ot energy sources remain the
highest priorities of the Government. The Bank's involvement in this
sector will continue through selective concentration on the
development of hydropower through assistance to a major hydropower
project each year. In addition, support will be provided to develop
the coordinating capabilities of relevant planning institutions to
enable them to work out the capital investment requirements of the
energy sector. The Bank program in Malaysia also includes continuance
of assistance for development of stratcgic sea ports for facilitating
exports.
37. Another area assuming increa'ing importance for the Bank's
future lending will be assistance to the perceptibly growing private
sector which will partly replace the public sector. Though still at a
conceptual stage, the program is likely to assume concrete shape after
the current exercise of identifying areas of privatization and framing
guidelines is over. The Bank's response to the private sector could
be in the form of equity participation and/or financing ot private
industries, either directly or through DFIs; this may call for a
gradual shift in the strategic thrust of Bank lending.

14
III. THE PROJECT
38. A report entitled "Appraisal of the Third Penang Port
Expansion Project in Malaysia" (Report No. MAL:A-48)is circulated
herewith.
A. Objective and Scope
39. The proposed Project represents the Bank's third phase
assistance for the expansion program of the Penang Port. The main
objective of the Project is to enable the port to handle its rapidly
increasing container traffic satisfactorily and to provide additional
conventional cargo handling capacity. The Project will provide the
port with a container handling capacity of about 250,000 TEUs 1/ per
year through the construction of a new container terminal at North
Butterworth -- the North Butterworth Container Terminal (NBCT) -- on
the west coast of Peninsular Malaysia, capable of accommodating either
one third (2,500-3,000 TEU capacity) and one second (1,500 TEU)
generation container vessels or three first (700-800 TEll) generation
vessels. The terminal will be provided with cargo/container handling
equipment and modern port facilities adequate to handle the forecast
level of export and import cargoes up to the year 1997-1998. The
proposed Project consists of the following main components:
(1) reclamation of about 41.6 ha of land area for a
container marshalling yard, two container freight
stations and ancillary areas;
(ii) construction of a 530 m long and 60 m wide wharf on
piles, including a mooring dolphin, and a 520 m long
and 19 m wide access bridge connecting the wharf with
the reclaimed back-up area along the shore;
(iii) paving of the port area, construction of port
buildings, including container freight stations,
administration buildings, maintenance and civil
engineering workshops, gate houses, training
facilities, an internal roads system, amenities and
ancillary facilities, and the installation of neces-
sary utilities;
(iv) provision of container/cargo handling equipment, such
as gantry cranes, transtainer cranes, front-end
loaders, prime movers, trailers, forklifts, mobile
workshops and mini-buses with all necessary spare
parts;

Cv) provision of a 3,000 HP tug boat equipped with
fire-fighting facilities for berthing and unberthing
ships;
(vi) acquisition of land and water areas;
(vii) provision of consultant services for detailed
engineering designs and construction supervision; and
(viii) provision of a training program.
40. The layout plan for the container terminal, as proposed
under the Bank-financed Phase Ill feasibility study, comprised the
construction of a new container terminal with a 530 m wharf alongside
water depth of 13 m below Admiralty Chart Datum 1/, and a back-up area
of about 24 ha immediately behind the wharf. The proposed scope,
however, required costly reclamation in deepwater and soil replacement
works for foundation settlement. As the least cost solution, a
revised layout for the construction of an island type wharf connected
by an access bridge with back-up area facilities located on the sea
shore has been agreed to between the Government, the Bank and the
Penang Port Commission (PPC); the revised layout comprises the scope
of the proposed Project.
41. To connect the Project container terminal with the country's
road network, a road section of about 100 m will be required to
connect the Project internal road system with Federal Route No. 1.
The Government has undertaken to have this section constructed by
30 June 1987. For further improvement of the traffic flow between the
terminal and the hinterland, the Government has also agreed to give
priority to a section between Federal Route No. 1 and the North-South
Expressway during the construction of the planned Southern Approach of
the East-West Highway. The Malayan Railway plans to connect the
container terminal with the national railway network. For that
purpose, the Malayan Railways intends to commission a study to
determine the most suitable and viable option for the construction of
the proposed link. It was agreed that this study will also include
the assessment of economic viability. The Project layout includes the
provision of land space for such a railway connection which, however,
will only be constructed if its economic viability can be clearly
demonstrated.
42. The total Project site covers an area of 45.8 ha, of which
41.b ha will be obtained by reclamation of land in the shallow water
area. PPC will acquire all land and water areas and rights of land
reclamation over the seabed from the Land Department of Penang State,
by 30 June 1985.

C. Project Organization and Implementation
1. Executing Agency
48. As in the case of the previous two Bank loans for the
expansion of Penang Port, the Penang Port Commission (PPC) will act as
the Executing Agency for the proposed Project and will assume overall
responsibility for its coordination and implementation. PPC was
established in 1955 as a statutory body with administrative and fiscal
autonomy, subject to a certain control by the Minister of Transport.
PPC's financial performance on the whole has been satisfactory and its
financial management is considered effective. PPC has executed the
two previous two Bank-financed Projects satisfactorily.
49. For the purpose of executing the Project, PPC will, by the

The Project Office will be responsible for the day-to-day execution of
the Project, including the procurement of goods and services, the

of the training programs, and the review and monitoring of the
progress of the Project. For the efficient operation of the Project
container terminal, PPC will establish a separate NBCT Operation Unit

3. lmplementation Schedule
51. It is anticipated that the proposed Project will be
implemented over a four-year period, commencing September 1984. The
following represent the main implementation events: preparation of
the detailed engineering design-tender documents and the
prequalification of contractors will be finalized by April 1986; the

4. Accounts and Audit
52. PPC will establish and maintain separate accounts for the

5. Project Benefit Monitoring
53. PPC will compile the base-line data and minimum data
requirement in order to monitor the actual benefits of the Project.
Such data include the volume of conventional and containerized cargo
traffic; the size, type and number of vessels; berth occupancy; the
rate of cargo handling equipment downtime; and a comparison of various
shipping costs.	 PPC will submit Project benefit and monitoring
reports to the Bank for review and comment quarterly for the first two
years of operations and thereafter annually. The PPC's statistical
reporting system, which Is comprehensive and satisfactory, will
provide a sound basis for monitoring, project performance and
operational improvement as well as for the planning of future

D. Justification, Benefits and Risks
54. The proposed Project provides an essential link in the
development efforts of the Government. International trade, which
accounts for nearly 50 per cent of the country's GDP, requires the
timely expansion of the cargo handling capacity of the port system in
Peninsular Malaysia.
55. The proposed Project will enable Penang Port to handle the
rapidly increasing container traffic satisfactorily. The port traffic
trend grew at an average rate of 7.4 per cent per annum during
1976-1983, and is forecast to continue growing at an annual rate of
4.4 per cent until 1989 and 4.2 per cent thereafter. The total
container traffic to be handled at Penang Port is forecast to increase
from about 86,000 TEUs in 1983 to 146,000 TElls in 1989 and about
250,000 TEUs in 1997-1998, representing an average annual growth rate
of 9.1 per cent for 1983-1989 and 65 per cent for 1989-1999. The
rapidly Increasing port traffic and the high penetration of
containerization have resulted in full utilization of port facilities,
and led to congestion, especially at the container and conventional
berths. All container traffic at the Port will be transferred to the
new and separate Project container handling facilities on their
completion. The Project container terminal, with a handling capacity
of about 250,000 TEUs per year, Is expected to meet the container
traffic requirements up to 1997-1998, while the existing facilities
will handle the conventional general cargoes. The Project will thus
contribute to the Port's cargo handling capacity and ease its
congestion.
56. Based on forecast incremental container traffic and the
latest cost estimates for the Project, the financial internal rate of
return (FIRR) is 6.5 per cent. On the basis of readily available
quantifiable economic costs and benefits, the economic internal rate
of return (E1RR) is estimated at 14 per cent.
57. No significant risks are associated with the proposed
Project.
